Risk Management Plan Executive Summary for CS-08



Description of Corporate Prevention and Emergency Response Approach



This OREG 2, Inc. (OREG2) Recovered Energy Generation (REG) facility complies with numerous standards for pressure vessel design and testing as well as all Federal and North Dakota process safety management requirements. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. Copies of emergency response, process hazard analyses and process safety management documents and all technical drawing (P&IDS) for process equipment are accessible at the onsite location for reference. Regular inspection and testing of the pentane and thermal oil systems are performed to ensure equipment integrity is maintained. The facility is equipped with a network of leak detection equipment, automatic shutdown logic controls, insulation, safety relief valves, fire detection monitors. OREG2 provides high levels of training in operating procedures, safety and emergency response. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to implement the emergency response procedures to mitigate damages, and to notify the local responding fire department.



Description of Stationary Source



The OREG 2 process is located adjacent to a gas pipeline compressor station.  The pipeline compressor is driven by a natural gas turbine.  The OREG process is fueled by waste heat from the gas compressor's turbine exhaust.  



Waste heat is converted to electrical energy by utilizing organic Rankine cycle (ORC) technology. The hot gases of the turbine exhaust flow through a Waste Heat Oil Heater (WHOH), where the heat from the gases is transferred to a thermal oil heat transfer fluid.  The heat transfer fluid reaches a maximum temperature of 572?F.  The thermal oil is then circulated to the shell and tube heat exchangers of an Ormat Energy Converter (OEC). The motive fluid (pentane) on the shell side is vaporized and these vapors drive an organic fluid turbine. The turbi

ne drives a generator which produces grid-compatible power. The turbine exhaust vapors are then condensed in an air-cooled heat exchanger and enter the cycle again as a liquid. On the thermal oil side of the heat exchangers, after exiting the heat exchangers, the thermal oil is routed through a thermal oil surge tank, thermal oil feed pumps, and back to the WHOH. 



The power from this project is sold to Basin Electric Power Cooperative based in Bismarck, ND.  The facility is rated at 6000 KW. The net power output to the electrical grid is rated at 5100 KW. Power output is reduced in warm weather due to limitations of the air cooled heat exchangers.



Use of Regulated Substance



Pentane, a flammable vapor/liquid is used as the working fluid in the organic Rankine cycle. Liquid pentane is pumped from a condenser to shell and tube heat exchangers. Thermal energy provided by thermal oil is transferred to the pentane. The thermal oil heat input causes the pentane to change physical states from liquid to high pressure superheated vapor that is passed through a turbine to produce electric power. The vapor is condensed and recycled back to a pressurized liquid recuperator vessel to complete the Rankine cycle. A pentane storage tank is available for makeup. The facility design is segregated into multiple sections, each having its own design specifications dictated by the pentane conditions in that section. The sections include: the low pressure process equipment, the high pressure process equipment, pentane unloading system, vapor recovery system, evacuation system and non-condensable removal system. Each section is protected by pressure relief systems that may include pressure safety valves, pressure control valves, control system shutdown and intervention logic and administrative practices.



Quantities Handled or Stored



The pentane is normally found in both the operating and static portions of the process.  When in operation, the majority of the pentane is found

in the working process.  There is some additional pentane present in the connected storage tank.  For the purpose of defining registration quantities, a fully-charged operating system is assumed plus a storage tank that contains up to 3,500 gallons.  The basis for the registration quantities is as follows:

Worst Case Scenario Description



Worst case scenario is based on a vapor cloud explosion. Although safeguards are in place to make a worst case scenario extremely unlikely, it was assumed that the explosion was the result of the release of pentane from a full pentane storage tank, which represents the largest single container onsite.  The tank is assumed to be filled to 80% of water capacity. ______________________________________________

The RMP comp model is a conservative screening tool and may overestimate distances to endpoint. 



OREG2 CS-8 REG facility is located in a relatively isolated area surrounded by farmland. The facility is located approximately 6.8 miles north-northeast of Zeeland, ND.  Examination of topographic maps, aerial photographs and visual observation of the potentially affected area in a worst case scenario did not identify any residential structures or parks.  However, this facility is adjacent to the compressor station that provides th

e heat source and this station is within the affected area.  The compressor station staff is not employed by Ormat, nor does Ormat control their access to the compressor station.  Given this proximity to public receptors, this facility cannot qualify for an RMP program level 1. In the initial RMP submittal, compressor station employees were not considered public receptors; hence, a program level 1 was designated.  Although program level 1 was initially designated, the OREG always had a program level 3 prevention program in place.



Alternate Case Scenario Description



The alternate case scenario is based on a pool fire.  The pool is formed upon a hose rupture that occurs during tanker truck offloading to the pentane storage tank.  It is very conservatively assumed that it takes approximately 10 minutes to stop the flow.

Prevention Program Description



Process Safety Information:  Design information, including Process Flow Diagrams, Piping & Instrument Diagrams, Plant Control Logic, Safe Limits, and Safety System Description, is available on site.



Process Hazard Analysis: OREG2 utilizes personnel experienced in organic Rankine power cycles to perform a hazard analysis appropriate to the complexity of the process for identifying, evaluating, and controlling hazards involved in the process. A HAZOP analysis was selected and utilized.



The o

riginal process hazard analysis was revalidated in August, 2009.



Standard Operating Procedures:  Operating procedures are developed to address plant startup, shutdown, normal operation and monitoring, and emergency shutdown.



Training: Some equipment in the OREG2 facilities poses potential fire, explosion, and electrical hazards that could cause serious personal injuries and costly property damage if procedures are not followed correctly. Personnel are trained in standard operating procedures and emergency response procedures.  Additionally, safety training, conducted monthly and required of all employees, identifies the different hazards to be found on the sites. These subjects include electrical safety, fire prevention and protection, lock out and tag out procedures, hazard communication, gas detectors, fire panels, personal protective equipment, and the safe use of tools and equipment. Safety training is supplemented by the use of the Industrial Hygiene and Standard safety procedures manuals.



Maintenance: OREG2 management tracks maintenance on electronic spreadsheets. Maintenance documentation includes information on all equipment in the facility requiring maintenance, inspection, testing, certification, calibration, etc. NFPA, OSHA, manufacturer's recommendations and operations experience have been utilized to produce a comprehensive maintenance tasks that are scheduled and assigned to plant personnel. Employees report any equipment deficiencies to the Operation and Maintenance Manager who generates work orders for the repair or assessment of the problem. Routine comprehensive inspections are performed using checklists.



Accident History: OREG2 CS-08 REG facility has not had any reportable accidents.



Safety Systems: The principal methods of accident prevention include equipment design safeguards, written procedures and operator training. Safety systems are present in the plant that provide alarms and control interlocks to place the process in a safe

state.



High pressure safety systems are one such example.  An initial alarm alerts the control room operator both audibly and visually of the pressure rise.  This initial alarm affords the operator the opportunity to take some corrective action.  If the pressure rise continues unabated, automatic shutdown of select process equipment is initiated to mitigate the problem.  If the initial alarm and subsequent shutdown fail to mitigate the pressure rise, pressure safety valves are in place to relieve to pressure to the atmosphere or to larger, low pressure systems. 



A combustible gas detection system is present in each of the plants. Sensors are strategically located in each plant. Control Room audio and visual alarms annunciate concentrations in excess of 40% of LEL.  



Emergency Response Plan: OREG2 personnel are trained to recognize emergencies, mitigate the emergency to the extent possible, and notify local emergency responders and Northern Border Pipeline personnel.  Plant personnel do not fight pentane fires.  



Upon detection of a pentane fire, personnel are instructed to initiate automatic shutdown of the process which removes heat, closes isolation valves and depressurizes equipment.  OREG 2 and Northern Border Pipeline personnel are then alerted of the need to evacuate the site.  Responding fire department personnel assume incident command upon arrival.





Callout protocol: If any of the following alarm conditions are indicated by the OREG2 monitoring system, the call-out protocol must be followed: OEC failure, security/fire alarm trip. If any of these events should occur the monitoring staff will immediately contact the Operation and Maintenance (O&M) Manager. If the O&M Manager is not reached in a timely manner the parent company, Ormat Nevada Inc. will be notified on the 24 hour phone number (775) 852-1912. If a fire is detected, the monitoring staff shall notify local emergency personnel including fire and police departments.



Notification o

f Northern Pipeline Personnel: Any Northern Border Pipeline personnel which may be at the site during the alarm condition must also be notified through Northern Border Pipeline procedures. Northern Border Pipeline personnel do not respond to alarm conditions at OREG 2.
